I’ve just finished my first blind playthrough, and I have lots to say.

The Letter took me on one of the most gripping rides I’ve had in a while from fiction. I knew this VN had the potential to be great from its Kickstarter, which I duly backed. Throughout development, Yangyang Mobile ran a slick show, and I’d hold it as a good example as to how a good Kickstarter is run. Does it live up to the hype?

Yes and no. I’ll explain.

From the outset, The Letter draws you in with a well-crafted atmosphere. Good writing and beautiful art really heighten the emotion of a given scene. I enjoyed the unique style which evokes anime though in a grittier fashion – a bit of a risk that pays of very well, helping establish the mood of the game. Overall, it hooks you with stellar character-driven drama, I was enthralled by the interaction between the protagonists and how they react to the plot driving forward.

This excellence however causes a bit of an issue. It’s not really of the horror genre now. It has elements of it (certainly some scenes did a good job of getting that horror feeling!), but I thought it overall underdelivers on horror. I think this is the point from some of the negative reviews I’ve read that resonates with me the most. The focus is on the character interaction. I think some people expected something a bit faster paced and in your face – and its honestly not unwarranted. Nevertheless, in this drama aspect, The Letter truly shines – but that’s not what we expected. And overall, the horror aspect of a ghost cursing people is basically The Ring/Grudge – it’s not exactly breaking new ground there.

I was however put off by a lot of bugs and typos throughout the game. While of course that can be patched, and Yangyang have been quite good at that, it’s a bit disappointing to see yet another game pushed out still a bit buggy. I’d raise complaints if it was any other developer.

Nevertheless, I thought the VN still had plenty of strengths, and that’s further bolstered by the excellent soundtrack and well produced vocal theme songs -  I can’t wait for the OST DLC! And the voice acting is suprisingly great - don't lie, we all groaned a bit at 'english voice acting' -  subs not dubs! This is a great exception - the voice acting is excellent.

Overall, I’ve recommend waiting a few patches down the line, maybe a sale, before you pick this one up. If you can stand unvoiced lines and typos, you can go ahead and buy now. Just as long as you do get it, because it is a great VN – probably the best Original English VN on the market right now (though that’s not too hard – looking at you, ‘Stay! Stay! DPRK!’). Let people know that the baka gaijin can make serious VNs too!

SCORE: 7.5/10

*Voice acting is top notch. Really, fantastic job to everyone involved in the VA.
*Characters are deep, VERY different, and multilayered. Each have their own internal conflicts, perspectives, and personalities. The first person voice of the game really nails it.
*Choices that matter. AND I MEAN MATTER. There are nearly 200 achievements in the game, and even after 41 hours of gameplay, I still don't have them all. I STILL HAVEN'T SEEN EVERY ENDING. And, without spoiling anything, you can get endings that range from "feel-good" to "melancholic" to "truly horrific".
*The horror. As someone who is not particularly a fan of jump scares, there was never a time I felt as though the game offered cheap thrills. The real horror isn't even in these moments (although they certainly add to the tension); it's in what the experience does to the characters.
*Music and sound. Brilliant. Not much to say other than spot on.
*The writing. Apart from some grammar mistakes, particularly involving "would" and "could" (specifically, the absence of them where appropriate), the writing is gripping, and written in the voice of each of the characters. So strong is the writing that, even in the absence of all the other positives, this still would have made for a fantastic novel.
*Visible branches. Ever wanted to know exactly why your decisions mattered, or where something changed? The game provides you with an entire tree which shows the paths you've taken previously, just in case you wanna try something different. Why don't more games do this?

The Less Great
*Especially towards the latter parts of the game, there are missing audio clips, audio clips which play in the wrong place, missing words, repeated words, and other slight inconsistencies. Yangyang Mobile are working hard to correct these errors, so hopefully they'll be fixed soon!
*You can't name your save files, or delete them for that matter. It's a minor thing, but given the amount of other conveniences they've included in the game, it really sticks out like a sore thumb.

If you're looking for a visual novel with memorable characters, legitimate scares, great dialogue, a very branching narrative, choices that matter, awesome visuals, and fantastic music, you're asking for a lot in a game...

But The Letter delivers.

[h1] [quote=Luke] "I understand it now, it was not for her missgivings as mother, it's for all the what if's, could have's and should have's. Things that never be because it's far too late"	[/quote][/h1]

The Letter ist eine erst kürzlich erschienene Visual Novel der Marke Horror, Mystery und Drama. Wie in anderen Spielen dieser Art, ist es Aufgabe des Spielers, sich in die Geschichte einzufühlen, an ihr teilzunehmen als passiver Beobachter, meistens jedenfalls. Denn es gibt einige Quick Time Events und viele, wirklich überaus viele Entscheidungen zu treffen, welche natürlich der Spieler übernimmt und die weiß Gott nicht einfach und mit dem Tode eines heißgeliebten Charakters enden können...

[h1] Handlung [/h1]
Die Handlung dreht sich um die seltsamen Geschehnisse um das Ermengarde-Herrenhaus im fiktiven Städtchen Luxebourne. Seit jeher Ranken sie seltsamste Gerüchte über das Anwesen und ihre letzten Bewohner, ein vor Jahrhunderten verstorbener Lord und Lady. Klingt klischeehaft? Ist es aber definitiv nicht. Die junge, ehrgeizige Isabella Santos ist im Auftrag ihrer Immobilienfirma und mit Hilfe ihrer Kollegin Rose Cooper, nun daran, diese seit so vielen Jahren verlassene Villa an neue Besitzer zu verkaufen. Jedoch findet sie bei einem Rundgang einen seltsamen Brief, der ihr Leben und dass der Leute um sie herum drastisch verändern wird.

[h1] Charaktere [/h1]
Die Geschichte wird in sieben Kapiteln erzählt und dreht sich immer um die Tage zwischen dem 17. Oktober und 1. November. In jedem Kapitel schlüpft man in die Rolle von einer anderen einzigartigen Figur, welche alle über die eine oder andere Weise miteinander in Verbindung stehen. Ob die abergläubige Immobilienmaklerin Isabella, die vornehme Mathematikerin Hannah, der gutmütige Fotograph Zachary, die ehrgeizige Architektin Marianne, die toughe Lehrerin Rebecca, der rationale Detektiv Ashton oder der exzentrische Unternehmer Luke, man lernt sie ausnahmslos alle sehr detailliert kennen und lieben. Auch die Nebencharaktere waren meiner Meinung nach sehr gut ausgearbeitet und sympathisch.

[h1] Atmosphäre [/h1]
Der Zeichenstil ist sehr hübsch, und die Bewegungen flüssig und schön anzusehen. Ein ganz besonderer Augenschmaus sind natürlich die größeren Szenen welche mit einem sehr schönen teilweise statischem, aber auch manchmal animierten Bild aufwarten können. Die Musik trägt auch viel zur Stimmung bei. Besonders gefielen mir hierbei die gesungenen Parts. Die Sprecher sind überaus talentiert und professionell zur Sache gegangen. Ich muss dazu sagen, dass ich englischen Sprechern immer etwas skeptisch gegenüberstehe und deswegen andere Visual Novels wie CLANNAD oder Amnesia deswegen auf japanisch gespielt habe, einfach weil mir dort die Synchro wesentlich besser gefallen hat. Nicht jedoch hier, die englische Synchronisation brauch sich echt nicht zu verstecken.


Jetzt noch ein paar Wörter zu den Achievements. Es gibt hier unheimlich viele verschiedene Enden, was den Wiederspielwert ohne hin schon sehr hoch ansetzt. Ich bin generell eher ein Mensch, der schnell das Interesse an einem Spiel verliert, jedoch will ich hier erst aufhören, bis ich wirklich jedes Geheimnis gelüftet habe, und es gibt massig davon. 172 Achievements gibt es insgesamt und mir fehlen nunmehr drei, welche so unglaublich schwer zu bekommen sind, wegen der schlichtweg gigantischen Zahl an Möglichkeiten.

Alles in allem ist es eine sehr gelungene VN, und ich freue mich bereits darauf, mehr von den Entwicklern zu sehen!!

33985006.review:
So first thing's first--I haven't played the game to its full extent BUT I have finished my first playthrough. As a visual novel, it was fantastic--I love Isabella and Ashton and Zachary and more than anything I love the LGBT representation woven into the game. Each character has a deep backstory that really plays into the game and makes you feel for them. The voice acting, art, and soundtrack are phenomenal. I really, really love this game.

That being said, if you're looking for a strict "horror" genre visual novel then this is probably not the game for you. Are there some disturbing, grotesque images of death and carnage? Yes. Just as I was trying to do a different playthrough today I had to witness Isabella get absolutely obliterated by a car. Do we have a ghost? Yes! However, "The Letter" plays off of a lot of horror movie cliches--we've got a spooky, abandoned mansion whose original owners mysteriously died. Lots of urban legends surround it. It just went up on the market! Someone buys it and is surprised that it's haunted. And there's a mysterious chain letter that ties everyone into the curse. Don't get me wrong, this isn't necessarily a bad thing! In fact, the game plays off of these very well! But if you're looking for intestines on the walls and jumpscares that make you wet yourself, then this is not for you. If you're going for a more psychological horror game merged with a dope anime, you've come to the right place.

What also was interesting was that the game is broken into seven chapters. Each chapter focuses on the POV of one of the seven main characters--Isabella, Hannah, Zachary, Rebecca, Ashton, and Luke. This was really cool. REALLY cool. Reading each character's thoughts and feelings on a situation really envelops you in the story, and each character is written uniquely according to his or her personality. It was fantastic--but here's my two cents on it.

Of all the characters to end the game on, WHY Luke? Maybe it was just the choices I made and how I just got a very standard ending in my first playthrough, but... why? To put it bluntly, Luke is the biggest jerk in the whole game. He is racist, narcissistic, and at the end of the game when I was in the heat of the moment it felt like Luke did everything he could to diffuse the building tension in the worst possible way. I understand he's selfish and has an "every man for himself" attitude, but his anger and refusal to listen and pay attention to the other people around him made me want to bash my head into my keyboard. All the other chapters certainly made up for it, but still.

One other thing I'd like to address is that some of the audio files for certain lines of dialogue were either absent or read incorrectly, and this became much more prevalent at the end of the game. It may just be a glitch or a bug but it was still sort of jarring to be emotionally invested in a scene and then hear just dead silence when another character is supposed to say something.

The QTE were nigh impossible at some points but that's probably why they're called "quick-time events"--you have the option to skip them though, which is nice sometimes but it made me feel like I was missing out. Basically, git gud.

Overall, though, The Letter is freaking fantastic. I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun new VN to play. I think it's getting horribly overshadowed by Dream Daddy (no shade to Dream Daddy) and I would love to see more people fall as much in love with this game as I did. Please, play this game! You won't regret it.

33962939.review:
I picked up the game not expecting a whole lot. It's a Western Visual Novel with what seems to be a load of cliche tropes and characters. I'm glad I bought it. The Letter manages to make every overused elements of a typical horror story works and on top of that it brings to the table a degree of character building I wasn't expecting. Short version is this: This is an excellent Horror Visual Novel, and if you remove the Horror part, it's an excellent Visual Novel as well.

The premise is perhaps not the most innovative. Haunted mansion. Cursed object. A sizable cast of distinctive characters. A creepy the ring-esque monster woman. The Letter has all the makings of another Horror Story 101, and indeed if it was a film there may not be anything entirely unique about it. What makes the Letter stands out is in its outstanding presentation. The game uses the format of a Visual Novel to make the story much more engaging than it theoretically has any right to.

One of the more impressive element of the game is its cast of characters. A large number of characters isn't entirely new in horror movies. After all, to raise tension, people have to start dying. Characters in a horror story then are often there for practical purpose. Sometimes they're given more depth. Sometimes they serve their purpose and get off the stage. On the surface, this is potentially the case with the Letter. Any character can die. But simply because this is a Visual Novel, their death hold much more meaning. The reason is simple: You are forced to spend hours in their shoes before their potential death. You have to get a handle on their personality and mindset, and then you have to get to know them as people, know their hopes and aspirations, fears and insecurities. Because you get to know them as people first, knowing you could potentially end this person's life just by choosing wrong is harrowing in a way that no passive medium like films or books can manage. The Letter has no protagonist. No one has the plot armor. If your character reaches an ending where they die, the story moves on without them, and the story branches appropriately. The game took me approximately 14 hours to complete the first time, but because very choice have an impact of some kind, the game feels much more dynamic despite being in a way more linear than most visual novels. There is a specific end point you will reach, but the staggering variations you can take to get there as well as the number of possible outcomes after the game finishes mean that your playthrough feel much more personal and involving than it would in most other visual novels. The Letter is perhaps the best example I know of where pseudo-linearity is done so masterfully it trumps branching pathways.

Supplementing this are the characters themselves. They are a diverse bunch with more depth than I expected at first glance. Despite what I had suspected, I enjoyed every chapter, each of which is from the perspective of one of the seven playable characters. Despite being marketed as a Horror Visual Novel, I personally find the character building aspect of the story more engaging than the horror aspect, and the horror aspect as I said is rather excellent. On top of this, their relationship is a joy to watch. I find myself unabashedly excited when I see two characters interact for the first time, knowing their differences will make for a spectacle. Other times, seeing an interaction from one character's perspective before seeing the same interaction from the other character's point of view does wonders in illuminating both their circumstances and points of view. The Letter may not be the first Visual Novel to do this, but it's certainly the one that made me wish this was done a lot more in this medium.

The game is very impressive in term of Production Value as well. The sound effect is appropriately creepy when it needs to be. The soundtrack sets the mood competently even if it may not be very memorable. The voice acting is a joy to listen to (though I can't attest to how authentic the accents are, I do find them terribly entertaining, especially Luke's). The CGs are beautiful or harrowing. The static sprites are expressive and generally excellent. The animated sprites and backgrounds help make the game looks more dynamic than almost any other game of this genre. The Letter looks and sounds much better than most other visual novels on the market right now and it's doubly surprising considering this is Yangyang Mobile's first game on Steam.

In my personal playthrough, I encountered a couple of minor technical hiccups. The Story Branch function does not work for Chapter 7. There are rare instances when dialogue are not accompanied by any voice acting at all, or when the written dialogue does not entirely match up with what the character is saying. There are also one or two minor typos here and there, but rare enough that I never thought to keep count. These are incredibly minor problems however, and are completely overshadowed by the otherwise impressive technical feats the game has accomplished. Since the Letter is quite new as of the time I finished the game, it's likely the developer will iron these out in time.

I do have two main criticisms for the game, and both have to do with the ending. Firstly, I personally find the climax unsatisfying. There are two endings the average players will likely encounter, and let's just say even the achievement seems to be aware of how ridiculously anti-climatic they are. There is a True Ending, and while it is somewhat less of an anti-climax, I personally think that the story did not build up to this path enough for the story to conclude satisfactorily. Furthermore, even the true ending leaves several questions unanswered. I enjoy the variations you can achieve in the Epilogue, but considering of how impressive the rest of the game is, the fact that they are still, uncolored images narrated by a dozen or so lines of text for each character leaves me thinking they could have put a tad more effort into them. The other criticism I have is in the nature of the True Ending itself. I personally believe that the existence of a True Path reduces meanings from all other paths. Sometimes, this is necessary. For the Letter, I am on the fence on whether it is. Furthermore, achieving the True Ending is incredibly unintuitive. To avoid spoilers, I'll only say that you have to do several things that most players would consider "failing." It is interesting for a Visual Novel to force the player to go against their instinct as a player, but as far as I know (and there's a chance I'm wrong), there is very little to indicate what you need to do and why you need to do these things to achieve the True Ending other than trial and error.

Still, these problems are only a small portion of the entire story, and they do very little to distract from how impressive the rest of the game is. Long story short, the Letter is an excellent Visual Novel that uses its medium to greatly enhance both its horror elements and character building. On top of that, it looks and sounds impressive and should be seen just to see how much you can do to make the format of the medium fresh again. If you are a fan of horror stories or Western Visual Novels in general, I would strongly recommend picking up the Letter.

How can I describe the Letter in one phrase? Very polished yet underwhelming in some aspects. Note that at this point I have only played apparently 50% of the achievements and am open to my opinion being changed if I locate new paths. 

Don't get me wrong, I can see that there were some unique positive elements: 

Pros:
[list]
[*]The art: The sprites are animated, which is cool to seem them move. The CGs are also "animated" frames that were also mighty impressive. Also the characters as drawn in the CGs were generally consistent with the sprites, always a good sign. The ghost as depicted is quite spooky and it was thrilling to be caught off guard from the jumpscares! 
[*]Audio: Music in general was forgettable, which is both good and bad - it did its job of setting the atmosphere for scenes. The sounds the ghost make are probably the most salient, adding to the spooky mood of the scenes when she appears. 
[*]Character bonds: I'm not using development, but the bonds they already had starting out were nice to see, and it often wove into each of their complex and usually dark pasts. Because their bonds are already there, there isn't much more development in terms of growing them, but there is in maintaining them, which presumably emphasizes that friendships take hard work. 
[/list]

Pass:
[list]
[*]Gameplay: Note that I disabled QTE (being scared by her presence is enough for me!) so I can't comment on the QTE, but it is a rare feature in most visual novels and thus a plus that they incorporated some gameplay in here. Personally I prefer the game play in 999 where you find clues and piece things together, other people may have different tastes. 
[/list]

Cons:

[*]The endings: I was rather disappointed by the quality of endings, though I should've suspected from the 50+ endings that there are. If you've ever played Princess Maker series or Prince Maker: Braveness, you'll know what I'm talking about. Endings that don't really feel complete, and may become a mish-mash of the sum total of relationships you've saved and relationships you've neglected. To me, the ending is a key part of how I judge my VNs, and these endings definitely miss that key memorable quality. An open ending is fine, but they shouldn't be so forgettable I could interchange them and it has little to no impact on building any attachment to the character. Also [spoiler] how did Luke get no jail time despite repeatedly admitting to killing people to climb higher? [/spoiler]
[*]Skip function: This may be a side note, but many times I found the same lines and scenarios being repeated without me being able to skip them due to letting a different character die. It grew irksome and drew attention to how much repetition there was due to the same scene being shown through the eyes of three or four different characters. 
[*]Narrative: Adding to the above, due to the order the perspectives were shown, some characters near the end [spoiler] Luke [/spoiler] missed out on some development. There were some pivotal scenes that I wish I could have read what they were thinking, because then I have to infer things about them that might not be true, a skill more reserved for real people I deal with. 
[*]Relationships: On purpose I went for the more "odd" romances to see if it was possible, which sometimes was for the endings [spoiler] Ashton with Zach is not possible, fyi its friendship-only[/spoiler]. However, throughout the narrative per above, I didn't see the scenes play out through the eyes of the other character, making it more of a one-sided love. Throughout the narrative it was clear what the "main" romantic relationships was going to be [spoiler] Ashton with Isabella and Luke and Hannah [/spoiler]. Thus, the other relationships weren't really possible in a sense. I also wanted to see relationships break down in Battle-Royale style but didn't much of that thinking except brief thoughts from Luke.  
[/list]

[u][b] Overall [/b][/u]
Would I recommend a buy? Yes, for the price of two movie tickets, you get 10+ hours of entertainment, why not? Plus, you're supporting growing the Visual Novel western marketplace with games that aren't about 'moe girls harems lulz'.
There's just the caveat you might find the plot build up disappointing and the endings incomplete, but the characters' bonds with each other from their shared experiences is heartwarming to see.

33943015.review:
Loved it! Absolutely love it!

I love horror movies and have watched so many that I think I've become permanently deranged. Either way! I bought this game thinking it was a super interesting concept for a VN, given that they are usually self-indulgent evolutions of trashy romance novels. And it was -- a super interesting VN that is, not a trashy romance novel (the romances aren't even a big deal, other than as character motivations and depth). You can easily see the influence of movies like the Grudge and the Ring here, but one of the things that impressed me was that each "jump scare" scene with the ghost was different. She hits a lot of horror tropes (under the bed, in a mirror, out of a closet) but never does the same thing twice (not to mention how the same concept for the Grudge that annoyed me -- her stalking people with no seeming logic or rules -- was actually pulled off here really well in contrast). Each character's death is uniquely terrifying and disturbing and really makes this feel like a horror movie/novel hybrid. As much as I wanted everyone to live happily ever after, it was actually so much better to have most or all of them die (especially when a certain character has all of his friends die in quick succession while he is helpless to do anything to save them). There's sex, there's violence. There's racism and allusions to rape. But all of it is done tastefully and none of it seemed gratuitous. That's a HARD thing to accomplish with any genre, but especially horror.

I agree with some other reviewers that this is definitely the best VN I have ever played, worlds ahead of any other. The 3D graphics make everything 10x better rather than 10x worse (like I thought they would). I don't think the creep factor could've been accomplished a fraction as well without it. The QTEs are great too (I didn't realize you could auto-win them until later too). 

The voice acting is SUPERB, though the writing can get a little stilted in some places (nothing new to VNs!) and, I swear, it's like every character has to inner monologue before EVERYTHING they say sometimes ... it's still great. I think the VAs doing Hannah and Rebecca were phenomenal, and a certain death scene atop a building with a certain someone making a last, tearful phone call to the person they love before dying is the most beautiful one in the game (my opinion). I was absolutely blown away by how much emotion and authenticity was put into each performance, even those I was worried about being flat. The VAs actually made the script come to life in a way that had me wanting to hear nothing but dialog the whole game (I originally thought I'd have to turn the sound off to not ruin the lines, but gave it a shot before I did).

It seemed like they wanted to please a bunch of different interests here, hitting a lot of varied elements all within the same game/story. And somehow, they succeeded. I don't know how. And this has ruined me for other VNs, but that's okay. I hated myself for playing VNs anyways. 

10/10, would blindly stumble into ghost-murder again! I assume everyone who plays it dies seven days later?

~Lorraine

33917141.review:
The effort that went into this game is phenomenal; I'm completely mindblown at the complexity of the game's story structure. The Letter gives players tons of choices that allow them to craft how the story unfolds. Mind you, it's a massive game and you'll find yourself overwhelmed at the branching trees with each passing chapter. 

If you aren't used to horror games like myself, then you'll find yourself disturbed and feeling unsafe at night. Fortunately, the entirety of the game isn't in a horror setting; there is plenty of heartwarming moments and world-building in-between the scary segments. The writing is sophisticated, and I find myself being well-informed of various cultural dialects and slang. My favorites so far are "bubble and squeak" and "bobfoc". There are "triggering elements" in the story: racial slurs, incest, and the like, but they make for pretty natural storytelling. They aren't there to harm anyone experiencing the story, of course. They are simply a respectable awareness, and I commend the developers for that.

Every story-shifting choice you make will affect the other characters in later chapters. They will mourn deaths. They will remember what you say.

Be advised that there is a ton of narrative text in the game. If you are just looking to scream and entertain your Youtube viewers, then there's gonna be PLENTY of waiting time for them. It's a visual novel first and foremost, but when the horror stuff happens, it HAPPENS HARDCORE. The artwork and animation in the game really bring pivotal moments to life. The CGs are animated, as well as the talking sprites. The talking sprites have a more cartoonish look compared to their promotional art counterparts, but that's likely because it was easier to skeletal animate. 

The music sets the mood perfectly, and luckily for us scaredy-cats, the ominous tracks warn when a spook is about to happen. MOST of the time, at least.

[h1]Pros +[/h1]

[b]Artwork[/b]
In short I was blown away by some of the rather exquisite artwork that is featured in this game. Sure, some images were reused for some scenes as is usually the case in VNs but the sheer amount of images in the gallery alone (I haven't even unlocked all of them) says a lot about the dedication the team had. Not to mention the fact that the majority of the game is animated, even if it's just something simple such as lip movement as a character is speaking.

[b]Story[/b]
When I wasn't looking at how darn pretty the artwork is, I found myself quite heavily immersed in the story. Truth be told, the game wasn't so scary for me as psychologically thrilling, but the whole character development and backstories definitely kept me intrigued besides that. There is also the fact I haven't done other routes yet, except a fairly safe route: [spoiler]like keeping everyone alive[/spoiler]. I like to think that it's definitely a good thing that the game isn't focused solely on scaring the crap out of you... for me it gives it more meaning.

[b]Characters[/b]
In total there are 7 characters in which you get to play throughout the game - each character having its own chapter in the story. The choices you make in this game count towards the progression of the story. Your interactions between characters affects their relationships with each other as well as within which path you will take. Each character has their own unique quirks that make them likeable as well as realistic. I found myself enjoying every single one of them that I played - to say the least, their stories were all equally fascinating to me. 

[b]Sound[/b]
I'll admit, at first the voice acting was a huge turn off. Partially because I don't tend to play visual novels with english voice acting, but also partially because the voice acting wasn't entirely convincing - maybe the issue is that I'm English and it's where the VN is set. That aside though, with how much I enjoyed the whole experience surrounding this VN, I soon got used to the voices (even if some were re-used for different characters) and it wasn't an issue anymore after the first chapter. 

Aside from the voice acting, the chilling sound effects like the screaming, clicking and all those to be expected from a VN inspired heavily by series such as the grudge, was a good touch. Especially when combined with quick-time events. This did actually add the right amount of tension and atmosphere, which is very, [i]very[/i] important in a horror game. And finally even the background music was a very well-thought out part of the VN, whether that be eerie sounds breaking through the night or classical music to denote the joyful sides of each chapter. [h1]Cons -[/h1]

I went into this VN fully expecting it to scare me, but in actuality most of the game focuses on the characters and their lives. Sure, there are brief intermissions of horror but definitely not the higher amount that I originally expected. That said, I still rate this VN highly for anyone who enjoys psychological horror games - and a gripping story in general.

After completing the game one time, I must say that the Letter lives up to its name as a Horror Visual Novel.

The horror is definitely inspired by The Ring and Ju-ON as stated in the description of the game, but also reminds me of Until Dawn with its branching tree with each chapters.     

Speaking of the chapters, each of seven chapters are played by one of the seven characters that are introduced in the game that saw the"Letter". Each character chapter talks about how they deal with not only the curse of the Letter, but also their own burdens whether is past or present, which sometimes the antagoinist uses against them throughout the chapter. As mention before, each chapter has its own branching tree so they're many ways that the story can play out and needs to be play more than once in order to get every ending there is. 33888589.review:
"The Letter" is the best visual novel I've every played, and I'm not making statements like this lightly. I think, the last time I wrote something like that, was in my review for "Danganronpa" and this game... Oh, boy, this game offers so much more than I was expecting.

[h1]What's great?[/h1]

[b]Plot. [/b]Simple, but interesting concept (remember those annoying chain letters?) gets turned into something incredibly complicated and engaging. It was obviously inspired by Asian horror movies [spoiler]pale lady, long black hair all over her face, crawling around and making scary noises[/spoiler] - yes, we've seen it a thousands of times, but it was done in truly outstanding way. You have curse, you have hunted mansion, mysteries of the past, yadda, yadda, all those classic horror elements, but everything works perfectly, thus showing, that cliches aren't necessary a bad thing, as long as you use them to tell a compelling story.

[b]Characters.[/b] There are seven main characters, each one with their own chapter, each with their own issues, interests and decisions, that will impact not only the main story, but their relationship with each other. The best thing any story can do, is make you care about characters. With horrors, it's especially important, since it makes everything much more engaging and tense. I cared about every single one them - Becca, Ash, Belle, Zach, Hannah, Marianne, even Luke. [spoiler] Yes, Luke! Guy, I literally hated during first four chapters, to then completely change my mind and consider him my favorite protagonist - that proves how good the writing for this game is.[/spoiler] Characters are complicated and even though I found some of their behaviors unrealistic, it was never breaking the immersion.

[b]Visuals![/b] Moving sprites. Moving backgrounds. Moving CGs. I generally don't care that much about visual side of games, but here, art is not only incredible, but also adds so much to the atmosphere. [spoiler]Whenever the monster shows up... Wow. I could feel like something is crawling on my skin. [/spoiler]

[b]Sounds. [/b]This is literally the most important thing, when we talk about horror games. "The Letter" has amazing sound design. The music is great, it always fits the atmosphere of the scenes, and sounds, no matter if it we talk about frightening screams or gentle laughs, or some stuff going in the background, make this game incredibly immersive experience. Also, it has voice acting. I don't like to play visual novels with V/A, but I've turned it on during few scenes, and it's good.

[b]Fear.[/b] Fear, just as humor, is very subjective thing. Games like FNAF and dozens of "Fnaf wannabies" made a lot of people believe that jumpscares are just cheap horror tricks, with no substance. I disagree with that - good jumpscare, in the right moment, is something that will make your skin crawl. This game has jumpscares - great jumpscares, may I add. It also has gore. It has psychological horror. It has pretty much everything you could expect from a title like this. Whatever you enjoy, when it comes to horror, you won't be disappointed.

[b]Choices matters.[/b] Finally. Even those little ones, that affects how characters think about each other, how they react in certain situations, and so on. But there are also big choices. The one that affects who survive and who doesn't, how the story will go, and how will it end. "The Letter" offers more branching paths than I've ever seen, with many endings and possibilities. 

[h1]In short:[/h1] 

If you like either good horror stories, or good visual novels, it's a must have. It's absolutely worth the price, visuals are outstanding and pretty much set a new level for other games in that genre, the sound design is amazing, voice acting is good, plot is deep and engaging, with great characters and both darker and lighter moments. Add to that, important choices and branching paths, and you have a nearly perfect game. Or just perfect. I think "The Letter" fully deserves this sort of praise.

-The cast is wonderful and has great interaction with each other. The close group of Ashton, Becca, Bella and Zach was especially loveable. Supporting characters were also well done, though some like Father Norman could have benefitted from more screentime.

33827648.review:
The TL;DR version of this review is that The Letter is hands down THE best English Visual Novel produced to date. My usual rating system for Visual Novels are: Story, Graphics, Audio, Gameplay and Characters.

Story:
This is a horror themed visual novel, and it has some of the best writing I've seen. While the plot may not be the most intriguing ever, it is tightly woven in the sense that it covers - as far as I can see - everything that you may question about the game. For example, there are 7 main characters in the game. What if 2 characters die? What if A, B and D dies specifically? How will it affect the narration? What kind of responses from the characters are expected? You can try any combination you like, and you will notice that there are tidbits here and there in the narration that will fill in the gaps and enrich the experiences. It is an amazing effort.

Normally, ghost stories love confining characters to a single setting - just the mansion! Just the hotel! Cut off all communications for XXX lousy reasons! - but no. The ghost originates from the mansion and haunts the mansion in ways you dare not imagine, but it also hunts the characters over different places fluidly. It is not bound to one place, and the characters aren't bound to one place (well on the larger scale everyone is bound on the city, planet Earth, the universe yada yada but you get my point). 

This makes for a very organic and realistic experience that is even better than most Japanese Visual Novels out there, since those games usually have locations that are so systematically defined it feels like there are only X amount of locations that exist in the whole general setting (i.e. XXX City). The point is, the world does not feel small here. You will be visiting various settings in the city such as a theater, a mansion, a hostel, an apartment, rooms, a police station, a library, a church, and office and so on. The world is big. It is not just X girls' houses / school / your house and the end, and that is great.

Graphics:
I'm honestly in awe at the graphics. While I can't claim that it has the best damn graphics in the entire world, it has a unified color tone, excellent background and character sprites and CGs that are ALL ANIMATED. And boy do they look lovely when animated. The CGs especially are fantastic. The beautiful CGs are beautiful, and the creepy CGs are downright terrifying. It's like I'm watching a movie, but with the best shots framed at every second. And did I mention the ghost? The ghost is going to haunt you. You're going shut your eyes in midnight, and ungodly and grosteque shapes will naturally float to your imagination and accompany you in your dreams. It is a gorgeous experience.

And the gore. Oh, my god. The gore. I will never wipe the image of poor Isabella from my mind. I personally love Marianne's because of how... immoral it is. Oh, sweet temptation of sins.

This level of quality is going to spoil me. This is already starting to make some Japanese animation graphics look LAME. That's how good it is.

Audio:
First, before everything else related to audio, I must applaud the English VA. How ironic that a Philipines produced Visual Novel has some of THE BEST English voiceacting I've ever heard. This is movie level quality, if not better because movies have the tendency to go absolutely over the board (Batman, seriously, can you fucking speak NORMALLY for once and not like you're going to murder every cat in the house). This also applies to Japanese VA, which while almost always high quality, takes the word 'overboard' and shoots it all the way to the edge of the galaxy. I never understood why people like high pitched loli voices that are so high pitched the piano probably can't fit said pitch. Kids don't talk like that. HUMANS don't talk like that unless they have a fucking condition, jesus.

TL;DR the voiceacting is awesome. This is handsdown the best English VA I've ever heard from a Visual Novel, and among the absolute best even when compared to Japanese VA. Actually, I doubt there's going to be any Japanese dub that's going to outdo the original VA. I do not believe there will.

Now, onto BGM and sound effects. My judgment in BGM is kinda weak, so I'm just going to say that it's beautiful and well designed. The creepy moments are creepy, the touching moments are touching, it's... really good.

The sound effects? The game will spook you (or get you prepared for the horror that it's about to unleash upon you) right from the beginning when you click New Game. For some people, the clicking noise is going to scare them every time they hear something similar for the rest of their lives. To say that the sound effects of this game are top notch is a horrendous understatement.

Gameplay:
As with most visual novels, gameplay elements are few in this game, using QTE elements to enhance the immersion and experience of horror. But if you think that is the weak point of The Letter, I'm sorry not sorry to tell you that the QTE designs of the game put many modern game QTEs out there to shame. Normally you think QTEs as boring. Normally they're just a nuiscance and considered the 'easy' way out of what could've been a satisfying boss fight. In The Letter, when a painfully sharp and well defined mangled head is taking up 90% of your screen and attempting to kill you, the last thing in your mind when dealing with the QTE is ANYTHING but 'boring' or 'easy'. It's hard. You are being fucking murdered by a supernatural being after all, so it's only natural that it's hard.

But it's not hard without purpose either. You'll notice that the QTEs are designed to fit the scenario appropriately. Button mash (there is only 1 button mash QTE in the game as far as I'm aware, and it's at the very start of the game)? Well that's because your character is trying to wrench the bloody door knob open. Metronome? That's because you're trying to control your breathing and heartbeat in a situation where both are out of control. There's even one that pans the camera horizontally non-stop - and literally, because your character is holding a camera - as you attempt to take a photo of a certain thing in complete darkness...

If there's one flaw to the game, it would be that there aren't enough QTE moments. No kidding. I quite wish I could be spooked more often, if only because they are so compelling to play.

Characters:
Let alone visual novels, this level of characterisation puts games, movies and books to SHAME. Most stories have a character stick to one personality trait and stay there forever. Not this game. Every person is complicated, and every person is a living contradiction. The label 'one dimensional' do not exist in the characters of this game. The writers don't hold back on profanity. The writers don't hold back on issues like racism. Some writers hold back when they try to write a racist character for example, but the writer here states it as the character would have had it. It was a pleasure to read. It's even funny to see people get offended by it by the various behaviors displayed by the characters. I can't even come up with the words to describe the cast of this game, just, play it already.

Conclusion:
Before I started to play this game, I jokingly thought that the devs had spent billions in development. After playing the game for thirty minutes billions is still an exeggeration, but I cannot help but think if they did spend millions at least on it. $20 for this game is a fucking STEAL.  How can you even price it this low it's RIDICULOUS. This is WAY BETTER than most of the localised Visual Novels currently present on Steam. Any Visual Novel fan who misses this will be missing out on a major milestone in EVN history, the best EVN to date and one of the best VNs in history.

Keep it up, devs! The Letter is right up there with VA-11 HALL-A, Clannad and a few others in my best Visual Novel of all times list!

40280294.review:
I don't always (or ever) play visual novels, but when I do, it's The Letter. 

Seriously, though, it's one of only two VN I'm in to right now. The Letter is the second of the two and I'm glad I took the plunge.

Seven playable characters greet you as you play through their view of the events of The Letter (there are many more important characters in this story - which is why I didn't say seven "main" characters). You see some common scenes where character routes cross and they meet, but you also see "that character only" content as each one approaches the situation their own way or using their own plans. Each character has a backstory that is reflected in their dialogue throughout the game as well as their initial relationship levels. 

They will have their own unique confrontations with the main antagonist, which are played out in the form of QTE (which are skippable if you wish with no penalty aside from losing a few achievements related to winning QTEs without skips). 

The QTEs are varied, depending on the situation the character is in when the confrontation occurs. Some are more challenging than others and tend to express how the character would deal with the confrontation.

And even then sometimes the confrontation lasts after the QTE and you make choices for the character's actions...and sometimes...those choices ARE the confrontation. 

The characters are voiced and the voice actors did a wonderful job throughout the game. Not once did I think of a voice being annoying or not fitting the lines being conveyed. The voices are diverse, showing the character's different backgrounds and their own mannerisms. 

The unvoiced lines, frequently what the character thinks or feels, are equally important. 

While by no means being a light-hearted story, there are moments of humor and fun. The characters banter and poke fun, other light events occur, and there's just some pleasant moments.  

The game is just well-made from start to finish. It's very polished and stable. I have yet to have any sort of crash or glitch in the game. The art is beautiful. The backgrounds are lively and realistic. The character portraits are expressive, and the CG scenes capture the big moments of the plot with a painting-style look to them and some animation as well. During the epilogues and the journal, you get a nice sketch style as well.

The music is beautiful. Characters have their own themes, which are used in various situations in the game as well as mood/background music even beyond just relating to that character. There's songs in the game that are completely beautiful for the opening, ending, and during one of the routes. The soundtrack is available for this game....highly recommend it.

And those endings. There's several endings and that might be an understatement. So many possibilities and all of them triggered by what you've done in each of the characters' chapters. 

Which brings me to the part of the game I might adore the most...choices matter. Pretty much all of them. They all either alter the route the characters take (including carrying over into other chapters), influence relationship levels (which can impact routes and endings), or shift the plot in a direction (sometimes changing a whole route, sometimes just altering how a scene plays out and the information you gain).

You can try to find the "right" choices, or try to think like the character (I would do this in his/her place so I'll pick this option). The game accomodates it even with the "simple" choices you have available. The options usually convey what the choice is saying about (or to) the character in question.

As far as what I don't like about The Letter...there isn't much I don't like. "Help Me"

Собственно, наконец-то я закончил с The Letter. Вообще, я бы мог закончить намного быстрее, если бы не принялся набивать 100% прохождение (гляньте в профиль, у меня там реально 172 из 172 ачивок) или включил бы вовремя инстант скип. Но в целом, я остался очень доволен.
Как бы описать The Letter?
Представьте, что у вас есть среднестатистический ужастик. Вот только вместо обычной однолинейности у нас есть куча вариантов дойти до конца, где не все в прямом смысле могут дожить. Это и есть The Letter.
У нас есть в наличии 7 глав и 7 протагонистов соответственно. Каждый протагонист обладает своей индивидуальностью и характером, так что хотя бы один точно должен вам зайти. Мой топ из женских персонажей - Изабелла, а из мужских - Зак. Отдельно хочется упомянуть про блондинчика Люка, который хоть по своему очень колоритный персонаж, но по сути то еще мудло, поэтому отношение к нему у меня двоякое.
Если уж это хоррор, то пару слов о хоррор-составляющей. The Letter канеш не напугает вас до чёртиков, но пару раз уж точно встряхнёт. Хотя я со временем привык к миленькому личику тёти призрака (кто она есть, можно при удачных обстоятельствах или с помощью стимовских гайдов узнать с 3 прохождений), но вот крипи лицо Кайли (да, я уже много раз про него всем говорил, особенно от него тащится Лиза :D) каждый раз хоть чутка но пугает меня :D.
Насчёт графона. Он вполне хорош. Чардиз персонажей вполне себе напоминает Тима Бёртона. Но вот только честно говоря, хотелось бы больше вариаций одёжек у спрайтов, а то местами было немного странно.
Музон тоже очень годный. Опенинг, эндинг, и инсерт сонг тру энда - просто космос.
Ну и в техническом плане всё норм. У нас есть анимированные CG, спрайты и BG. А также есть квик-тайм-ивенты, которые можно по возможности отключать.
Ну и из недостатков, которые лично я увидел:
1) У меня есть одно замечание по логике происходящего насчёт 4 главы, то бишь связанной с Мэриэнн.
Дело в том, что общий таймлайн идёт с 17 октября по 1 ноября. И в каждой главе есть свой период обозреваемого времени. Например, у Изабеллы в 1 главе с 21 октября по 24 октября, а у Ханны во второй главе с 17 по 28 число. Вот с таким разным временем обзора событий насчёт Мэриэн у меня есть пару замечаний насчёт логики. Я не буду спойлерить в чём там дело - если когда нибудь доберётесь - сами увидите.
2) Начиная с 5 главы, было замечено местами немалое количество неозвученных реплик. Плюс к этим техническим косякам можно добавить, что оттуда же встречалось парочку косяков с редактурой
3) Ну и местами повествование может показаться немного нудноватым.

А так, в целом данной новеллой я очень доволен. На выходе получился впринципе очень качественный OELVN продукт родом из Филипин.
К прочтению вполне рекомендуется.

P.S. В этом году разработчики обещали завести русский язык, так что ждите, кого заинтересует данное произведение))

39987211.review:
As a general rule, I dislike horror. Yet [i]The Letter[/i] did a fabulous job at entertaining me and making me feel emotions that extend beyond what the genre usually offers.

One of the first epithets that come to my mind when thinking about this game is « cinematic ». At least during the first playthrough (which has an average length of 25-30h), it felt like watching a serial, where you navigate in unknown waters during the first episodes before the pieces of the puzzles finally assemble. The division of the game into 7 chapters helped ensure that the reader would stay hooked for the next one, and learn how the new character would react to already known events and new ones alike. 
Some might find it tedious (because it involves re-reading some scenes several times), but I personally loved the introspective, almost psychological approach the developers chose with this game, allowing the player to delve into the mind of each protagonist while being privy to elements the character themself is yet to discover.

While the plot might not offer anything that could be deemed « ground-breaking », the characters clearly are the highlight of the game, as they feel palpable and real: they all come with their qualities and flaws (though one of them is *extremely* flawed, but is written as such on purpose), their aspirations, secrets and fears. It was a pleasure to navigate into each chapter and get to know each of them by learning their thought process and analysing the situation from their point of view. The relationships between them, mainly the friendship between Isabella, Rebecca, Zachary and Ashton, transpired genuineness. One of the quieter moments in which they reflect upon their bonds even brought me close to tears.

One could argue that the writing needs a bit more polishing, especially in the second half of the game (pertaining mainly to a couple grammatical errors), but these flaws are minor enough, and overall the game’s writing style is compelling and often shines throughout the dialogues. I especially appreciated the fact that the « bad choices » were not obvious to guess at all and often felt less like « X character is being mean because of unknown reasons » (something that I find grating in a lot of VNs) and more like « this character actually has good motivations to say something that might be badly received by their interlocutor ». Overall, these choices managed to give a better understanding of the characters at large. It is something that I feel is rare enough in visual novels in general, and deserves to be emphasised.

As far as the horror aspect is concerned, I found it extremely efficient and borderline nightmarish at the beginning. But since the jumpscares tend to use similar mechanics during the entire game, one might inevitably become desensitised to it on the long run. On the other hand, this allows the reader to focus more on the actual plot and characters, which is a win for me. This might also be an unpopular opinion, but I think the chapters that made the most use of psychological horror (especially Marianne’s) instead of simply relying on gore and creepy sounds were the best. 

I’d like to give a special mention to two key aspects of [i]The Letter[/i]. First, the art: the semi-realistic/semi-anime style mingled with some animation effectively breathes life into the game and is just beautiful to look at (at least in the scenes that don’t involve horror and gore, hm).
And last but certainly not least, the voice acting in this game is simply amazing. It’s lively, nuanced, and downright impressive at some key points of the game. I confess I have loaded several of my favourite moments several times after having finished the game just to listen to some of the dialogue again. Props to the cast and audio director!

TL;DR: [i]The Letter[/i] is a must for fans of visual novels: the writing of the characters, art and voice-acting are top-notch. And there is a LOT of content to read and unlock (CGs, achievements, epilogues), as well as a ton of variations, which gives it great replay value. While the plot could at some moments seem a bit dragged out, the outcome of the story and each character’s individual arc is still very satisfying, particularly when the True Ending is reached.
Especially recommended for people who favour character development, well-defined relationships and quality dialogue. Pure horror fans can give it a try, but I think it will mostly satisfy people who prefer a well-set creepy atmosphere and a general feeling of uneasiness to jumpscares and gore.
